dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: What's the obsession with sex?

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: It’s not an obsession. I’m not so sure I want to do it either. I'm scared too.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Scared is not the issue. It’s just that everything is so serious suddenly. We're not getting married. You’re going to Italy anyway for the summer and then to college. I just...we’re young, we shouldn’t tie each other down.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: What are you saying?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Nothing, it’s just I don’t want to feel pressure from you.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Do you like someone else? Your Dad's girlfriend?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: No...why...no! And she’s not his girlfriend.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: (she holds back tears) My father said you have a weak handshake which is a sign of indecision.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: (defensive) His hands are so huge, I can’t get a good grip.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: And my mother said that you don’t have a very good model for relationships because of your parents.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: What? Your mother doesn’t know anything. (thrown) I thought it went well. You told me she said I was hilarious. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She bursts into tears. Walt stands there, completely unprepared for her reaction. She just gets worse and worse, crying harder and harder.

dialogues.speaker: WALT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Stop it. Sophie. Stop it. Don't be difficult. Please. Her crying stops. She looks at Walt, Silence.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: I’m not being difficult. INT. LILI’'S ROOM - NIGHT 104 Walt sits on the bed next to Lili who’s in shorts, crosslegged. He looks depressed.

dialogues.speaker: LILI
dialogues.text: You want a beer? She rises and grabs two from a little fridge which is stocked with stuff.

dialogues.speaker: LILI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I couldn’t take relying on your Dad’s shopping habits anymore. You can have anything you want whenever.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: LILI
dialogues.text: I’m going to read you a draft of my new story. I want your thoughts < first. Then I’m gonna show it to your Dad. Lili lights up a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: LILI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You like Pink Floyd, huh?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: What? Walt tenses up, but she smiles warmly, indicating it’s okay.

dialogues.speaker: LILI
dialogues.text: Don’t worry, I used to hand in Lou Reed lyrics in my poetry class and pass them off as my own. Although I hope you don’t get caught. I always did. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She touches his arm. He and she lock eyes for a moment. Walt bows his head, his eyes on her bare thigh. The creas in her knee. He focuses in on this. The silence seems to go on forever.

dialogues.speaker: LILI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you--? Walt nervously swings his head up, clocking her in the nose.

dialogues.speaker: LILI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oww! Fuck.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Sorry! Her nose is bleeding.

dialogues.speaker: WALT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Lili, sorry. She gets up and looks in the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: LILI
dialogues.text: Shit. S’okay. Just a bloody nose.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: I‘m sorry. She goes into the bathroom. A moment. She comes out, her head tilted back, tissues soaking up the blood.

dialogues.speaker: LILI
dialogues.text: I think I might take a bath. Okay?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Oh... .okay. A pause. He realizes he’s supposed to go.

dialogues.speaker: WALT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Okay...

dialogues.speaker: LILI
dialogues.text: Night. He leaves the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walt shuffles toward his room, his Dad comes up the stair Stops in his tracks.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Hey .

dialogues.speaker: BERNARD
dialogues.text: Hey. Walt continues into his room and shuts the door. Bernard goes into Lili’s room. EXT. JOAN’S HOUSE - MORNING 106 Joan and Ivan pack up Ivan’s car. Frank stands on the stoop.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: When’s Bernard coming to get you?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: In an hour.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Plan on thirty minutes. He’s always early to get you. And late to bring you back.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I wish I could come with you guys.

dialogues.speaker: IVAN
dialogues.text: I heard that, brother.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: I know. But Dad's got you on Saturday. (pause) Do you like his girlfriend?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Is she his girlfriend?

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: I thought so. She lives with you. He doesn’t say?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: No. I think Walt loves her.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: So, they like the same women now too.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Nothing. You got our number in Maine. Remember to lock up.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I will. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: See you next week, Pickle-oo.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Just “Pickle” please.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: See you next week Just Pickle. They hug. He and Ivan shake hands.

dialogues.speaker: IVAN
dialogues.text: Good grip, brether. Just like Vitas.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: You too, brother. Frank watches, anxiously, as they start the car and drive away. INT. JOAN’S LIVING ROOM - MORNING 107 Frank waits at the window, looking out at the street. Checks his watch, Goes to the phone and dials. Machine,

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Dad, it’s me. Are you there? He waits and hangs up. Goes to the fridge and takes out a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A crisp spring day. Bernard’s Peugeot passes by.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. BERNARD'S PEUGEOT
dialogues.text: Bernard drives, Lili shotgun, Walt in back. Spirits are h

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bernard, Walt and Lili are welcomed by JEB GELBER, who wears a Sweater vest and bolo. INT. COLLEGE AUDITORIUM - DUSK lil Bernard reads from Under Water at a podium. Not a well attended event. Lili and Walt sit next to each other. His arm brushes hers on the arm rest. Bernard finishes. Applause. He grins. Gelber comes out and shakes his hand.

dialogues.speaker: GELBER
dialogues.text: {under his breath) Sorry about the turnout, lots of the kids go home early for Passover. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BERNARD
dialogues.text: (pleased anyway) They seem to like it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tangerine Dream’s El theme from Risky Business plays on t stereo, Frank, nude, drinking whiskey, stands at his * mother’s dresser going through old photos and jewelry. He finds some condoms. Takes one out of its wrapper, looks a it, smells it. And puts it on his penis. He walks over to a mirror and looks at himself. The condom slips off his * penis and lands on the floor. He retrieves it and tries t put it back on. On the bed, we now see, he’s laid out his mother’s underwear and bra and stockings on the comforter Leaning in to the mirror, he moves his nose around. Swigs from his whiskey glass. Suddenly he doesn’t feel so great He spits on the floor. Waits. He vomits. He runs to the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He throws up into the toilet. Tears stream down his face. He rolls over onto the tile. A moment. He sneezes. He looks into his hand and finds a cashew. CUT TO BLACK. INT/EXT. FRANK’S SCHOOL - DAY 114 Bernard and Joan stare at MS. LEMON, Frank’s principal. *

dialogues.speaker: BERNARD
dialogues.text: This seems quite impossible. Joan, stunned, says as if it’s happening to someone else:

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: The poor boy.

dialogues.speaker: MS. LEMON
dialogues.text: I mean, masturbating is his own issue. But Hector witnessed the locker incident and then later semen was found in the library...

dialogues.speaker: BERNARD
dialogues.text: Who’s Hector? Ms. Lemon indicates a CUSTODIAN over to the side, who nod politely.

dialogues.speaker: BERNARD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How do you know they were both Frank's, (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MS. LEMON
dialogues.text: Well, I suppose it’s possible other kids are masturbating and spreading their semen around the school as well...possible, yes, but also somewhat unlikely.

dialogues.speaker: BERNARD
dialogues.text: Oh, it happens I'm sure much more than we know.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Bernard, have you ever done something like this? Bernard looks at Ms. Lemon, who nervously looks away, the back at Joan. He says indignantly:

dialogues.speaker: BERNARD
dialogues.text: I’m not going to answer that.

dialogues.speaker: MS. LEMON
dialogues.text: Has anything been going on at home that might’ve provoked this behavior?

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Well, Bernard left him behind for three days last week.

dialogues.speaker: BERNARD
dialogues.text: (pause) And, of course, Frank’s mother divorced me earlier this year, which might also have something to do with it. (suddenly, to Joan) Did you tell Frank I’m unattractive?

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: No. He just doesn’t want your bone structure. They all stare at each other uncomfortably. EXT. FRANK’S SCHOOL - DAY 115 Ms. Lemon holds the front door for Bernard and Joan.

dialogues.speaker: MS. LEMON
dialogues.text: Ms. Berkman, I read your story in The New Yorker. I thought it was quite moving.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Oh, thanks. Thanks a lot. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Bernard’s expression is completely blank. Bernard and Joa start down the steps to the sidewalk.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You're living with a twenty year old.

dialogues.speaker: BERNARD
dialogues.text: It’s none of your business, Joan. She’s older than twenty.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: It’s my business when you have our kids. It’s confusing for them. Frank says Walt’s in love with her.

dialogues.speaker: BERNARD
dialogues.text: (hesitates) Walt has a girlfriend. (suddenly angry) Fuck off, Joan. I don’t ask about you and Ivan. Stay out of my life. I can’t believe you'd talk to me like this. You left all those fucking ticket stubs and letters lying around. You wanted me to know. It was fucking torture, Joan. Fucking torture. Pink Floyd's version of “Hey You". He walks to his car. He gets in, puts the key in the ignition, but doesn’t turn it. He sinks down slightly in chair. . INT. IVAN’S CAR - DAY 116 We FOLLOW Joan as she gets in. Frank sits in the passenge seat, staring at the floor. She looks at him. Takes a deep breath. Reaches over and touches his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Simic is now playing the Pink Floyd song for Bernard and Joan on a tape deck. Bernard reads the liner notes. They sit at desks across the aisle from each other and listen in silence. Simic turns it off. Joan absent mindedly peels skin off her lip.

dialogues.speaker: BERNARD
dialogues.text: He made his own interpretation.

dialogues.speaker: MR. SIMIC
dialogues.text: Well, he’s still going to have to give the prize money back. But obviously it’s a bigger problem. He isn’t doing any of his school work either. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BERNARD
dialogues.text: His paper on Gatsby was quite brilliant, I thought. It’s one of his favorite books.

dialogues.speaker: MR. SIMIC
dialogues.text: That may be, but I don’t believe he’s read it. (pause) You both should talk to him. Bernard turns to Joan. She’s already looking at him. She flicks some skin off her finger and says sadly:

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: I think Bernard has to do it. INT. WALT’S ROOM AT DAD'S - EVENING 118 Bernard stands in the doorway, Walt is on the floor with his guitar in his lap.

dialogues.speaker: BERNARD
dialogues.text: He wants you to see a therapist.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: I don’t need that.

dialogues.speaker: BERNARD
dialogues.text: That’s what I said. Does Simic know both your parents have Ph.D.’s in literature?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: I’ve mentioned it.

dialogues.speaker: BERNARD
dialogues.text: T think he’s full of shit. These public schools tend to hire well meaning, but ultimately unsophisticated bureaucrats.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Yeah. I don’t like him.

dialogues.speaker: BERNARD
dialogues.text: But you might have to do it. Just to please the school.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: I don't need it.

dialogues.speaker: BERNARD
dialogues.text: I know. And unfortunately probably a guy with a BA in psychology. Not a real shrink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walt sits across from the therapist, MR. WADDLES, 30’s, w is already answering a question of Walt’s.

dialogues.speaker: MR. WADDLES
dialogues.text: I have an MA in Developmental Psychology from the Yale Child Studies Program.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Did you get a PhD?

dialogues.speaker: MR. WADDLES
dialogues.text: No, an MA is a masters.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Uh huh. Right.

dialogues.speaker: MR. WADDLES
dialogues.text: Do you have any thoughts about why you're here, Walt?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Not really.

dialogues.speaker: MR. WADDLES
dialogues.text: Nothing?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: No. Waddles waits a moment, consults his notes.

dialogues.speaker: MR. WADDLES
dialogues.text: You said you wrote the song you played in assembly. .

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Uh huh.

dialogues.speaker: MR. WADDLES
dialogues.text: why?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: MR. WADDLES
dialogues.text: Did you have a reason?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: I felt I could've written it.

dialogues.speaker: MR. WADDLES
dialogues.text: Okay. But you didn’t. It was written by Roger Waters of Pink Floyd. TI think you know that. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence. A silence 81.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Yes, but I felt I could've so the fact that it was already written was kind of a technicality.

dialogues.speaker: MR. WADDLES
dialogues.text: I see. (pause) I can imagine this is a little uncomfortable for you to talk about.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: I guess. It’s hard to explain.

dialogues.speaker: MR. WADDLES
dialogues.text: I wonder how you're feeling right now.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: MR. WADDLES
dialogues.text: I’d like to know more about you. Why don’t you tell me about something less uncomfortable. A nice memory maybe.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Isn't that kind of a stock question for a shrink?

dialogues.speaker: MR. WADDLES
dialogues.text: Yes, that’s more or less how this works.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: I can’t think of anything right now.

dialogues.speaker: MR. WADDLES
dialogues.text: Just think.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Come on...

dialogues.speaker: MR. WADDLES
dialogues.text: Just something. Meet me half way here. as Walt thinks.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Umm...let’s see...okay, when I was around six, my Mom and I...she and I ducked out of Julie Glynn’s birthday party to watch “Robin Hood” together on our TV. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MR. WADDLES
dialogues.text: That sounds like a nice memory.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: I liked Errol Flynn.

dialogues.speaker: MR. WADDLES
dialogues.text: Errol Flynn. That’s all?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: And I was glad she let me leave the party early to watch the movie. She and I loved that movie. It's like...we were pals then...we’d do things together... we’d look at the knight armor at the Met, The scary fish at the Natural History Museum. I was always afraid of the squid and whale fighting. I can only look at it with my hands in front of my face. When we'd get home, after my bath, she’d go through all the different things we saw that day in the museum. And then we'd get to the squid and whale and she’d describe it for me which was still scary, but less scary and it was fun. It was fun to hear about it.

dialogues.speaker: MR. WADDLES
dialogues.text: Did your Dad live at home back then?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Yeah, why?

dialogues.speaker: MR. WADDLES
dialogues.text: You didn’t mention him. Where was he during all of this?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: He was...I don’t know exactly. Downstairs maybe. He didn’t ever come to the museum...This was...It was before my brother was born...before...it was earlier... Walt stops for a moment, choked up. He looks at Waddles with a surprised expression on his face. Waddles gives hi a “Not bad, eh?” shrug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walt opens the front door, drops his bookbag on the floor

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Hello? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: No answer. He goes up stairs. Looks in his Dad's room. It’s empty. Walks over to his room, throws his jacket on the bed. Goes over to Lili’s room. The door’s ajar. He hears: LILI’S VOICE I’m not...not now, Bernard. I’m not feeling like it. BERNARD’S VOICE Why not? LILI’S VOICE I'm just not, okay? Walt peers in. INT. LILI’S ROOM - CONTINUOUS 121 Bernard has his hand up Lili’s shirt, kneading her breast

dialogues.speaker: BERNARD
dialogues.text: Put me in your mouth. Lili’s eyes meet Walt’s over Bernard’s shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: LILI
dialogues.text: Walt...hi.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Hi. Bernard turns around to see his son. Walt just stares.

dialogues.speaker: BERNARD
dialogues.text: Hey, Walt.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: BERNARD
dialogues.text: I'll be right there, we can...hang out. Walt leaves. Lili takes Bernard's hands off her.

dialogues.speaker: LILI
dialogues.text: I don’t want to do this anymore. Lili walks to the other side of the cramped room. Bernard says nothing, looking both hurt and angry. He walks past her and down the stairs. INT. BERNARD’S PEUGEOT - DUSK 122 Bernard pulls up to Joan’s house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bernard rings the bell. Frank opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: BERNARD
dialogues.text: Hi. Is Walt here?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: BERNARD
dialogues.text: Oh. I‘d like you to come to my house.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Isn’t it Mom’s night?

dialogues.speaker: BERNARD
dialogues.text: Yeah, but I‘d like you to come over.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Umm, I have to put on my shoes. Come in, I guess. Bernard slowly follows him in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bernard reluctantly enters. Frank sits on the floor and starts putting on his sneakers.

dialogues.speaker: BERNARD
dialogues.text: Place looks different.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: She got some new furniture in Maine.

dialogues.speaker: BERNARD
dialogues.text: That was my TV. I bought that Tv.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Mmm mm. Bernard looks at the bookshelf.

dialogues.speaker: BERNARD
dialogues.text: That‘s my Jude The Obscure.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: You wanna take it?

dialogues.speaker: BERNARD
dialogues.text: Nah.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: She still has some of the books you wrote.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Bernard turns to the ceiling high shelves full of books. His eyes scan the titles. He finds the books with his nam on the spines. He can’t move. His face grows suddenly emotional.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Dad, why are you taking me to your house on Mom’s night?

dialogues.speaker: BERNARD
dialogues.text: Just a minute. He stands there, motionless, soaking in the place. For a brief moment, everything softens. His eyes grow watery. He takes a deep breath. All the change of the last few months seems to register. Joan enters from the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Oh...

dialogues.speaker: BERNARD
dialogues.text: Hi. Frank let me in. I didn’t realize you were here.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: I’m here. It’s Monday.

dialogues.speaker: BERNARD
dialogues.text: I’d like to take him for just tonight. I‘1l give you two Thursdays in a. row or something.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Mom...

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: It’s my night. He wants to stay. Bernard picks up a little toy soldier off an end table. Inspects it.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Be careful, that’s an antique.

dialogues.speaker: BERNARD
dialogues.text: Where’s Walt?

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: I don't know where Walt is. Bernard suddenly starts up the stairs. Joan tenses.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He’s not up there, Bernard. He doesn’t come here. He stops, remains there for a moment. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JOAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You should go. You’ll see them tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: BERNARD
dialogues.text: (to Frank) Tell Walt to call me. He comes down the stairs and goes to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walt looks in the window. His gaze goes from family to family, sharing plates, kids trying to eat with chopstick He finds Sophie and her parents at a table in the back. H watches for a beat, She suddenly looks up and spots him. He awkwardly ducks behind a menu that’s pasted to the glass. He waits a moment and peers back out. She’s still staring. He stares back too. Her parents turn and look at him. A moment. Walt ducks back. He waits. He peeks back out, but they’re not paying attention. He walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's getting darker. Walt runs along the path. He suddenly darts into the brush, pushing his way through th “trees. He emerges to a pond. No one is around. He walks toward it and stops. He stares out over the water. INT. BERNARD’S PEUGEOT/EXT. JOAN'S HOUSE - DUSK 127 Bernard sits in his car which is double parked. Starts it up, changes his mind, and puts it in park. He sees Walt running up the block. Walt, whose head is soaking wet, doesn’t see Bernard watching. Bernard waits for Walt to go inside Joan's, gets out of t car and approaches the house. He wades through the front garden and crouches down to the basement window. Inside, Frank, shirtless, sits on his bed with a beer. Bernard taps on the window. Frank looks up, startled. INT. JOAN’S LIVING ROOM - DUSK 128 Walt walks in, his hair and face wet. Joan enters from th kitchen. Her face lights up and she goes to hug him, but backs off just before reaching him, afraid of scaring him off.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Chicken, what happened?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: I dunked my head in that pond in the park. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: The one near the zoo? (he nods) Sweety, that’s filthy. I hope you didn't drink any of it. Joan retrieves a towel from the bathroom and hands it to Walt.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Some may have got in my mouth. I tried not to swallow. (pause) I shouldn’t‘ve broken up with Sophie.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Why did you?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: I thought I could do better.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Better how? Walt gives this some thought. His answer comes as a surprise to him.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: That's good you miss her.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Yeah, but I don’t see myself as a person who is in this situation. I just don’t. You know, I thought this could've been a real thing. A real love affair. I don’t see myself this way.

dialogues.speaker: _ JOAN
dialogues.text: Well, this is how it is.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Did you ever love Dad? Cause if you didn’t, why did you ever marry him? If you were going to leave him, why did you put us all through this.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: It wasn’t planned. When we first met, he was unlike anyone. In Columbus there was no one like your Dad. We were on the Ohio State campus and we'd take our sdiW@Ridhes out to the green and picnic together. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He asked me who I preferred: Antonioni or Fellini. I said Antonioni which was the right answer, I guess, at the time.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Is it Fellini now?

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: I don’t know. I think it’s whoever you like better. They make eye contact for a second.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I had had an affair with a man before your father. He worked in the college bookstore. We used to make love in the stock room. It got so that the smell of text books made me think of him.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Mom, I don’t want to hear about your affairs, please.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. I think I don’t know what I can say to you.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: You have a way of saying things sometimes that are a way I don’t want to hear them. Children shouldn't hear these things from their Moms. You should particularly watch it around Frank.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: I know, chicken, it’s something I do. It’s a bad habit.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Do you...do you remember when we watched “Robin Hood”? A moment, Joan jumps. Walt, startled, turns. Frank and Bernard stand in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: He knocked on my window.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Bernard, what are you doing? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BERNARD
dialogues.text: Joan, let me ask you something. All that work I did at the end of our marriage, making dinners, cleaning up, being more attentive. It never was going to make a difference, was it? You were leaving no matter what...

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: You never made a dinner.

dialogues.speaker: BERNARD
dialogues.text: I made burgers the time you had pneumonia.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Only after I insisted!

dialogues.speaker: BERNARD
dialogues.text: Well, if I had made more dinners would that've made a difference?

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: I was ready to leave a long time ago. I just didn’t know it then.

dialogues.speaker: BERNARD
dialogues.text: (hesitates) I’ve been giving it some thought. I mean, you called my father at the last minute. You said something. Whatever you said, he thought I could save the marriage. Bernard and Walt quickly meet eyes.

dialogues.speaker: BERNARD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You felt I wasn’t aggressive enough. I’1ll make more of an effort to do stuff. I’ve been cooking and doing chores at my house. I make veal cutlets which the boys love. Frank looks at his father as if to say, “What are you talking about?”

dialogues.speaker: BERNARD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Why don't we all have dinner and talk more about this. Joan starts to laugh. It catches her off guard. It’s clearly out of her control. She tries to stop, she sucks it in, but it erupts to a hysterical level. The two boys and Bernard watch her as she continues to shake and laugh Nobody says anything. Finally it dies down. She wipes the tears from her eyes. Coughs. She's exhausted. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: I‘m sorry... It’s just...burgers...once,. Joan loses it again, laughing, but struggles to control herself. Bernard sighs, saddened by this. But as it sinks in, he just grows angry.

dialogues.speaker: BERNARD
dialogues.text: I’1l sue you, Joan. You know I will. You had an affair for four years with that fucking shrink that ruined our marriage and I can get the kids. I talked to Eddie Goodman, who works on these cases all the time and I have an open and shut case. (pause) Frank, Walt, get in the car. A pause.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Sue me? That’s so...I can’t... You only wanted joint custody cause you pay less child support that way. Because it was cheaper for you. Joan stops herself. She pounds the top of the TV with her fist, upset she said what she did. Walt looks at his Dad, “Is this true?". Bernard goes to the front door and opens it. Street noise enters the house.

dialogues.speaker: BERNARD
dialogues.text: Walt, Frank!

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I don’t want to go.

dialogues.speaker: BERNARD
dialogues.text: I don’t give a shit. Frank, get in the car. Frank doesn’t move.

dialogues.speaker: BERNARD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Frank! Bernard grabs Frank's arm. Frank bursts into tears. Walt steps between them.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Let him stay.

dialogues.speaker: BERNARD
dialogues.text: I’m just asking this one thing. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: He wants to stay. Let him. I’1l go. Frank and Walt meet eyes. Frank’s nose is running, tears streaming down his face. Bernard turns to Walt.

dialogues.speaker: BERNARD
dialogues.text: Fine. Frank and Walt stare at one another for an extended momen

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Hold on... Frank kneels down, picks up the CAT and hands him to Walt

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You want him tonight?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Okay. Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: That’s alright, my brother. Bernard and Walt walk out the front door. 129 EXT. JOAN’S HOUSE - DUSK 129 Just as they step outside, the cat leaps out of Walt’s ar and into the street. Joan screams.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: The cat! It runs under a parked car. Bernard and Walt go after it, surrounding the car, Bernard taking the street side and Walt the curb. They both kneel down and look under the vehicle. The cat mews from beneath it. Bernard reaches under and grabs its tail. He and Walt meet eyes underneat the car.

dialogues.speaker: BERNARD
dialogues.text: I got him. Joan, I got him! I got him! He turns to Joan and Frank who watch from the stoop. His attention goes to a COP next to his double parked car, writing a ticket.

dialogues.speaker: BERNARD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Goddammit ! Bernard releases the cat who darts down the block and out of sight. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Dad! Bernard rises and starts toward the Cop.

dialogues.speaker: BERNARD
dialogues.text: I'm moving it! A car SCREECHES on the breaks and swerves just avoiding Bernard. The Cop looks up. The DRIVER yells, furious.

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: What’s your problem?

dialogues.speaker: BERNARD
dialogues.text: (under his breath) Fuck off. Ivan walks down the block toward them. He starts to pick up the pace. Walt turns to Frank who has wandered closer.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Did you see him go? Frank shakes his head, No and bursts into more tears.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Frank, go inside. Where is he?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: I don't know where he went. Bernard reaches the Cop. His face red, he’s panting. The Driver continues to shout at him. Ivan jogs over to the scene.

dialogues.speaker: IVAN
dialogues.text: What's going on?

dialogues.speaker: BERNARD
dialogues.text: I had him. Bernard’s breaths are audible, deep. He looks at the Cop. The Driver curses. Ivan next to him. Joan and his kids. H suddenly clutches his arm. And falls. Ivan drops to his side.

dialogues.speaker: IVAN
dialogues.text: Bernard? Are you okay, man? (pause) Joan, call an ambulance! Joan runs inside. Frank stares at Bernard. Walt races over and kneels down to his father. Bernard squints at Walt. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BERNARD
dialogues.text: Walt, get in the car.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, BROOKLYN STREET
dialogues.text: Bernard, awake, on a stretcher, is about to be loaded ont the back of an ambulance. Joan and Frank wait on the corner. Bernard says something to the PARAMEDICS and they stop for a moment as Bernard waves for Joan to come over. She approaches and leans down to him. He runs his thumb over his lips and looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: BERNARD
dialogues.text: “Degeulasse”.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: What? He starts to repeat the gesture, but stops self- consciously.

dialogues.speaker: BERNARD
dialogues.text: It means, “Bitch”. Don’t you remember?

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: You're calling me a bitch?

dialogues.speaker: BERNARD
dialogues.text: No, don’t you remember the last line in Godard’s *A Bout de Soufle”. Belmondo calls Seberg a bitch. “Degeulasse”. We saw it at the Thalia with the Dicksteins. I got you in for a children’s price. You were pregnant with Walt.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: (long pause} Like six weeks.

dialogues.speaker: BERNARD
dialogues.text: I still got you in for a children’s ticket. You told me you didn’t like Godard. You thought the jump cuts-- Bernard is suddenly thrust up in the air on the gurney an rolled inside.

dialogues.speaker: BERNARD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’d check for the cat behind the asheans under the Golodner‘s stoop!

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Okay. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: They meet eyes briefly. He gives a “Who would’ve thought” kind of shrug. She nods. Ivan and Walt climb into the back with Bernard and the door is shut. The ambulance pulls away. Silence. Joan and Frank start walking, surveying the block for the missing cat. Frank i bit stunned, his face smeared from crying.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Do you think we'll find him?

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: I hope so.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Do you think one day we could go to the Galapagos?

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: I don’t know, Pickle. (pause) Ivan and I could take you to the country on Saturday to see some real turtles.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Saturday's Dad’s day. We see them from a distance, alone on an empty street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The siren wails. Walt and Ivan sit in silence. Bernard is sedated in the back, a paramedic at his side.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: I didn’t write it.

dialogues.speaker: IVAN
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Pink Floyd did.

dialogues.speaker: IVAN
dialogues.text: It’s okay, brother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walt. peers in. His Dad lies on a bed, looking pale and thin, reading a detective novel. Bernard looks up, sees Walt and smiles sheepishly.

dialogues.speaker: BERNARD
dialogues.text: There’s my son. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Hey. Are you okay?

dialogues.speaker: BERNARD
dialogues.text: I’m fine. Thought it was a heartattack, but I think I’m just exhausted. Doctor said I’m exhausted.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Too many veal cutlets?

dialogues.speaker: BERNARD
dialogues.text: (smiles) Maybe.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Is that a good book?

dialogues.speaker: BERNARD
dialogues.text: Oh...this is pulp...it’s not serious... it’s...you know it’s hard to read a good book in the hospital. But this isn’t bad of its kind. Leonard is the filet of the crime genre. Walt is silent.

dialogues.speaker: BERNARD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'd like you to stay here for the day. I need the company.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: (pause) Okay.

dialogues.speaker: BERNARD
dialogues.text: Lili moved out. Bernard gives a “What can you do?” raise of his eyebrows, Walt nods.

dialogues.speaker: BERNARD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do me a favor, go out in the hall and get me another pillow, my neck is hurting. Walt doesn’t move. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Dad, you know how for my birthday you gave me Nikes.

dialogues.speaker: BERNARD
dialogues.text: What? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: How you gave me my Nikes as a birthday gift?

dialogues.speaker: BERNARD
dialogues.text: I wanted to get you something you could use.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: I know, but you know, since Mom gets me winter coats and you get me sneakers as part of your divorce...anyway...

dialogues.speaker: BERNARD
dialogues.text: In our separation agreement, it says I’m responsible for sneakers up to fifty dollars, those Nikes were over eighty.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Uh huh,

dialogues.speaker: BERNARD
dialogues.text: And I don’t think you told me anything else specific that you wanted.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: I know, I should’ve thought of some things.

dialogues.speaker: BERNARD
dialogues.text: You actually get more presents now since you get them from both your mother and me. When we were together we gave them jointly.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: I know. (flustered) And I like the sneakers so it doesn’t really matter. I’m not really angry anymore. It's just...what bothers me is you didn't...You didn’t try to... He trails off. A moment as Bernard takes this in.

dialogues.speaker: BERNARD
dialogues.text: I got you the sneakers.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: (takes a deep breath) Maybe we could even things out a bit and I could stay at Mom’s a few extra days since I’ve been staying more at yours... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BERNARD
dialogues.text: It’s not a good time right now, I’m not going to be a hundred percent for awhile. I’d like you around.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: I don’t think I want to come for a while.

dialogues.speaker: BERNARD
dialogues.text: It’s not up to you, Walt. You’re a minor. You're in my custody. My home is your home too.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: I’m not coming.

dialogues.speaker: BERNARD
dialogues.text: Why? Walt is about to say something. He doesn’t.

dialogues.speaker: BERNARD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That hurts my feelings. Walt looks surprised.

dialogues.speaker: BERNARD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don’t be difficult. If you like, we can get you some more posters or make your room better, paint it a different color. I got Frank a turtle. (indicating his blazer on the back of the chair) Look in the pocket of my jacket. Walt walks over to the coat, he feels in the pockets. removes a few little pieces of broken green clay. BERNARD (CONT’D) The guy said that was the best one. It’s got a blue dot on it or something that makes it worth more. Walt holds it out to Bernard. BERNARD (CONT’D) Mmm. I guess it didn’t survive the fall. Walt looks at the shards and dust in his hand. BERNARD (CONT‘D) We won’t tell Frank.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: No. 97. He (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Tears suddenly stream down Walt’s face.

dialogues.speaker: WALT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He would've liked it.

dialogues.speaker: BERNARD
dialogues.text: I could lend you my first edition of The Naked and The Dead. (pause) As a present.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Let me get you a pillow. Walt goes out the door in the hallway. He pauses for a moment, removes a pillow off a gurney and brings it back into the room. Bernard awkwardly lifts his head and Walt jams the pillow under his Dad’s neck. Bernard tries not t look at his son's crying, he presses the nurse button a f times, but doesn’t seem convinced it’s working. He finall looks at Walt, moved himself. Bernard's voice cracks as h says:

dialogues.speaker: BERNARD
dialogues.text: You used to be very emotional when you were younger. Walt nods. BERNARD (CONT’D) Did I look pretty silly out there, falling on the concrete?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: (pause) Yeah. Bernard bursts into laughter. Walt watches him curiously.

dialogues.speaker: WALT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What are you laughing at?

dialogues.speaker: BERNARD
dialogues.text: That was funny how you said, “Yeah”. Good comic timing.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Thanks. Bernard smiles at him warmly. He reaches out his hand. Walt takes it. Bernard squeezes it. .

dialogues.speaker: BERNARD
dialogues.text: Why don’t we get some breakfast. See if you can find the nurse out there. Walt starts for the door. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BERNARD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Try to get the blonde, she looks like a young Monica Vitti. Walt nods, turns and goes out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walt walks down the hall a bit. & Chinese NURSE approaches. He stopa in front of her. She looks at him. Silence. She waits for him to say something.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Excuse me. The man in that room wants to order some breakfast

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: Okay. Walt watches her disappear into Bernard’s room. Pause. He walks in the other direction. We FOLLOW him as he passes blonde Italian-looking nurse, goes by Ivan in the waiting room, reaches the elevatore, presses the button, He goes for the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He jogs down the stairs, clutching the rail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now he’s outside. Morning rush. A crowded sidewalk. He walks briskly for a bit. Turns a corner, keeps going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks, head down. He looks up. The Museum of Natural History, It’s just opening for the day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walt enters the room with the big whale hanging from the ceiling. He looks at the dioramas. Finding the one with the squid and the whale he mentioned to the shrink earlie He approaches it a bit warily. It’s dark and scary. He gazes into the black, finding the squid and then the whal We STAY on his face as he takes this in. Very slowly, he leans his head against the glass. And rests.
